awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Self-sustaining microbial photoelectrosynthesis for energy and fuel production
awd_abstract_narration:
Harnessing energy directly from sunlight and water presents a tremendous opportunity for a sustainable future. Artificial photosynthesis simulates plant processes to convert sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into renewable fuels and chemicals. Current artificial photosynthesis technologies have low efficiency and stability and require an external electrical voltage to sustain the conversion, which is energy intensive. Also, frequently, these systems require clean water for fuel production. This project will investigate the feasibility of a self-sustaining microbial photoelectrosynthesis process to solve both energy and water problems in solar to fuel conversions. Such modular systems can potentially transform expensive centralized energy and water infrastructure to more sustainable, flexible, and modular solutions. The investigators will train graduate and undergraduate students and actively involve underrepresented minorities and women. New course materials will be developed to promote interdisciplinary learning, and practicum based learning programs will be developed in conjunction with field service for communities. 

This project will investigate the integration of microbial electrochemical oxidation on the anode and photoelectrochemical reduction on the cathode in a combined system to produce fuels and electricity. By utilizing the potential generated from the anode, microbial photoelectrochemical systems can become self-sustaining without any external voltage application. The system does not require clean water to operate, rather it potentially cleans up wastewater via microbial organic oxidation. The project will study the underlying mechanisms of the interactions at both electrodes to achieve high current density and fuels production including hydrogen, syngas and methane. Fuel generation will be controlled by new individual catalyst systems designed for increased selectivity towards targeted products. Moreover, new anode catalysts will be applied to facilitate anode electron transfer and organic oxidation, and scalable reactor systems will be designed.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The project focuses on building novel microbial photoelectrosynthesis(MPEC) approaches for fuel generation and wastewater cleaning. It has no direct relationship with the work proposed herein. Using a microbial bioanode coupled with a photocathode, we gained fundamental insight into how to couple a bioelectrochemical system with semiconductor-based photoelectrodes. An article representing our first collaboration work showed that when coupling an gallium indium phosphide photocathode with a bacteria-based bioanode, a limited self-sustaining H2 evolution (0.4 mA/cm2, Energy & Environmental Technology, 2017, 51, 13494-13501) can be achieved. Later, we developed a MPEC system consisting a nanostructured Si photocathode coupled with two bioanodes. This system enabled a generation of a large photocurrent density (23 mA/cm2) by using only sunlight. Moreover, we demonstrated that on the bioanode side, wastewater can be converted into clean water ( Energy & Environmental Science, 2019,12, 1088-1099). Four related catalyst/catalyst interfaces were developed for more efficient H2 evolution during 2017-2021 (Nature Communication, 2019, 10, 982; Advanced Material Interfaces, 2019, ChemSusChem 2020, 13 (13), 3391-3403; Nature Communication, 2020, 11, 4114). Later, in 2020, we have developed a unique MPEC system that is capable of treating wastewater while converting carbon dioxide into syngas (mixture of hydrogen and oxygen) (Joule, 2020, 4(10), 2149-2161).  Broader Impact: This project will continue to broaden the team's understanding and experience in translating fundamental research into real world applications. During this grant, 12 undergraduate and three graduate students worked on this project, where more than half of students are women. Moreover, 10 out of 15 belong to underrepresented minority groups. 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2022
Modified by: Jing Gu
